The methanation of carbon dioxide via the Sabatier process is attracting growing attention for power-to-gas (P2G) application. In the current study, a series of 25 wt% Ni-based catalysts were synthesized using solution combustion synthesis (SCS) to investigate the influence of the support on the methanation performance. The results showed that Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited superior activity, achieving 72.5 % and 95.5 % CO2 conversion at 250 °C and 300 °C, respectively, while maintaining excellent stability over 100 h of time-on-stream. CO2-TPD analysis revealed that weak-to-moderate basic sites played a key role in enhancing catalytic activity. This is consistent with XPS results, which indicated a high concentration of surface hydroxyl groups and oxygen vacancies, responsible for the enhanced basicity of the CeO2-ZrO2 support. Additionally, the CO-chemisorption measurements confirmed improved Ni dispersion, further contributing to efficient H2 activation. In situ DRIFT-MS studies identified a reaction pathway involving CO2 adsorption as carbonate and bicarbonate species, followed by stepwise hydrogenation to methane via formate intermediates. The correlation between turnover frequency (TOF) and the number of weak-to-moderate basic sites supports a dual-site reaction mechanism, where basic sites facilitate CO2 activation and Ni sites promote H2 dissociation, both contributing to the remarkable low-temperature carbon dioxide methanation activity. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Ni catalysts Support effect Power-to-gas SNG production Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increasing concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is regarded as a major driver of global warming [1]. Consequently, several studies directed towards developing novel technologies aimed at reducing CO2 emissions by conversion into useful chemicals or fuels have been conducted [2,3]. CO2 hydrogenation to CH4, which is known as the Sabatier reaction, proceeds according to Eq. (1). Together with H2 production by water electrolysis, this is part of the power-to-gas (P2G) technology which links the power grid to the gas grid by transforming surplus power into a grid compatible gas [4]. Moreover, the existing gas network infrastructure provides high storage capacity and possibility to transfer methane conveniently and safely [5]. (1) CO2 + 4H2 ⇄ CH4 + 2H2O,ΔH0298K = −165.0 kJ·mol−1 CO2 methanation is coupled with the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction (Eq. (2)), which produces the main byproduct CO. Furthermore, the Boudouard (Eq. (3)) and CH4 decomposition (Eq.(4)) reactions lead to cooking and catalyst deactivation. (2) CO2 + H2 ⇄ CO + H2O,ΔH0298K = 42.1 kJ·mol−1 (3) 2CO ⇄ C + CO2,ΔH0298K = −173 kJ·mol−1 (4) CH4 ⇄ C + 2 H2,ΔH0298K = 75 kJ·mol−1 The CO2 hydrogenation into CH4 (Eq. (1)) is thermodynamically favoured at low temperatures and high pressures [6]. However, kinetic limitations require high temperatures and pressures to achieve appreciable CO2 conversion. Furthermore, the strongly exothermic nature of Eq. (1) generates a significant amount of heat, leading to severe hotspots within the reactor and, as a result, reduction of catalyst durability [7,8]. Consequently, the key challenge in CO2 hydrogenation is the development of active and stable catalysts for effective CO2 conversion at low temperatures [9]. Catalysts developed for CO2 methanation generally comprise group VIIIB metals, such as Ru, Rh, Ni, Co and Fe [10,11]. Amongst these, Ni-based catalysts are extensively used as a consequence of their low cost and relatively high activity and selectivity towards CO2 hydrogenation. However, their stability is often compromised by CO-poisoning of Ni active sites, causing catalyst deactivation due to carbon deposition and metal sintering [11,12]. The CO2 methanation activity of supported Ni catalyst has been reported to have a strongly dependence upon the nature of the support [13–16]. Several supports including Al2O3 [17,18], SiO2 [4,19], TiO2 [4,20], ZrO2 [21], CeO2 [13,22,23], and Y2O3 [24,25] have been studied. Indeed, the nature of support greatly affects the final properties of catalyst, i.e. morphology, acid/basic features, Ni-support interactions, dispersion and reducibility of Ni active phase, thus influencing the activity and extended-term performance of Ni-based catalysts [26–28]. Within this study, we focus on the effect of support on the catalytic behaviour of Ni catalysts. 25 wt% Ni-based catalysts supported on Y2O3, ZrO2, CeO2 and mixed (YZrOx, CeZrOx and CeYOx) oxides were made using solution combustion synthesis (SCS). The physicochemical properties of the synthesized catalysts were determined by N2-physisorption, XRD, CO-chemisorption, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, XPS, and TEM. Methanation of CO2 was investigated in the temperature range of 250–500°C, at constant stoichiometric H2/CO2 reactants ratio of 4 and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30,000–120,000 NmL·g−1·h−1. Catalytic tests were conducted at atmospheric pressure to evaluate the intrinsic catalytic activity without the complications of mass and heat transfer limitations, thereby enabling the fundamental insights into structure-activity relationships essential for the rational design of efficient catalysts. Furthermore, the formation of intermediates was investigated by in-situ DRIFT tests, to shed light on the mechanism of CO2 methanation over Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. A stability test over 100 h of time-on-stream was also performed over the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst at 250 and 300 °C. A comprehensive understanding of the structure-activity correlations in order to optimally design an effective catalyst for methane production by CO2 hydrogenation was targeted. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation High-purity chemicals purchased from Sigma-Aldrich were used without any treatment before use. Ni(NO3)3·6 H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, ZrO(NO3)2·H2O), and Y(NO3)3·6 H2O, were used as metal precursors, while urea (CH4N2O) was used as fuel. Ni-based catalysts were synthesized using the solution combustion synthesis (SCS) method as previously reported in the literature [25,29,30]. Typically, stoichiometric amounts of metal nitrates and urea were dissolved in the minimum quantity of distilled water. The mixture was left stirring at room temperature and was then subsequently transferred to a muffle furnace at 350 °C where combustion takes place yielding a voluminous powder due to the production of N2, CO2, and H2O gases [25,29,30]. The obtained powder was subjected to calcination in static air furnace at 600 °C for 2 h. Ni-based catalysts supported on Y2O3, ZrO2, CeO2 and mixed (YZrOx, CeZrOx and CeYOx) oxides were synthesized at fixed Ni loading of 25 wt%. The sample nomenclature and nominal composition are presented in Table 1. For brevity, the wt% content of each metal is designated in the catalyst name, e.g. 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 denotes a Ni-based catalyst containing 25 wt% of Ni, 20 wt% of CeO2, and 55 wt% of ZrO2. Catalyst compositions were confirmed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP/OES) employing a Thermo Scientific iCAP 6500 instrument. Before the reaction, the catalysts were reduced in-situ for 1 h with 40 NmL·min−1 50 % H2/N2 at 600°C. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The specific surface area (SABET) and the pore volume (PVBJH) were calculated by applying the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) models, respectively. Pore size distribution was evaluated through the density functional theory (DFT) method. Samples were degassed under high vacuum at 300 °C for 6 h prior to analysis. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed on Philips X-Pert 3710 diffractometer operating at 40 kV and 20 mA and over the 15° to 75° 2θ range. A sweep of 1.50°·min−1 was employed. Peaks were assigned using the PCPFWIN database. The lattice parameter (α) was calculated from Eq. (5) while the average crystallite size (L) was calculated via the Scherrer relation (Eq. (6)). (5) α = d ∙ h 2 + k 2 + l 2 (6) L = 0.9 ∙ λ β ∙ cos θ where d is the d-spacing calculated from the Bragg's Law, λ is the wavelength of the Cu-Kα radiation (1.5406 Å), β is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) and θ is the angular position of the NiO (111), CeO2 (111), ZrO2 (111), and Y2O3 (222) reflections. The reducibility of calcined catalysts was investigated using H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) on a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2750 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In these experiments, the sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor and heated to 600 °C at 10°C·min−1 under a 5 % H2/Ar gas mixture (30 NmL·min−1). The hydrogen consumption, used to determine the % metal oxide reduction, was determined based on the H2-TPR of a CuO standard. The basic surface properties of the reduced catalysts were analysed by CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) on the same instrument. Samples were reduced at 600 °C for 1 h under a 50 % H2/N2 flow (40 NmL·min−1), cooled to room temperature under He flow (30 NmL·min−1) and subsequently exposed for 30 min to a CO2 stream (30 NmL·min−1). The physisorbed CO2 was removed by purging with He for 1 h. CO2-TPD was carried out under He stream (30 NmL·min−1) over a temperature range of 20–600 °C with a heating rate of 10°C·min−1. The desorbed CO2 was monitored by TCD which had previously been calibrated using injections of pure CO2 pulses. CO-chemisorption measurements were conducted following reduction at 600°C for 1 h under a 50 % H2/N2 flow (40 NmL·min−1). At room temperature, the samples underwent the subsequent sequence: i) oxidation in O2 flow (30 Nml·min−1) for 15 min; ii) exposure to CO2 flow (30 Nml·min−1) for 15 min; iii) reduction in H2 flow (30 Nml·min−1) for 30 min. Finally, 10 % CO/He was introduced in pulses from a 600 μL chemisorption loop until the signal reached saturation. The Ni dispersion (D Ni ) was calculated from Eq. (7) (7) D Ni % = Ni s Ni t = f CO / Ni ∙ V CO ∙ M Ni 22414 ∙ L Ni ∙ d r ∙ 100 where fCO/Ni is the stoichiometric factor for CO chemisorption, VCO is the amount of CO chemisorbed on Ni, MNi is the molar mass of Ni, LNi is the Ni content in the catalyst, and dr is the reduction degree of Ni calculated from H2-TPR. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was conducted using a Philips CM12 instrument. Reduced samples were ultrasonically irradiated in isopropyl alcohol and then dispersed on holey-carbon copper grids. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured with a Physical Electronics GMBH PHI 5800–01 spectrometer operating with monochromatized Al-Kα radiation with a power beam of 300 W. Prior to the analysis, the catalyst was reduced under 50 % H2/N2 gas mixture (40 NmL·min−1) at 600 °C for 1 h thereby replicating the reduction condition employed during reaction. The BE regions of C 1 s (275–300 eV), O 1 s (520–540 eV), Ce 3d (875–925 eV), Zr 3d (175–190 eV), and Ni 2p (845–870 eV) were investigated, taking the C 1 s line (284.80 eV) of adventitious carbon as reference. Characterisation was conducted for fresh (after reduction) and used 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 samples. In-situ DRIFTS data were collected using a ThermoFisher Nicolet iS 50 R FT-IR spectrometer equipped with a Harrick Praying Mantis DRIFTS cell connected to a gas flow system. Exhaust gases were analyzed with a Hiden HPR-20 Mass Spectrometer. Approximately 100 mg of fresh catalyst was reduced at 600 °C for 1 h and cooled down to 150 °C. Prior to introducing CO2 and H2, the reduced catalyst was flushed with He for 20 min to remove residual H2. Stepwise heating with 10 °C increments up to 350 °C were applied with the temperature being held for 20 min at each step. 2.3 CO2 methanation Atmospheric pressure catalytic experiments were conducted in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (0.6 cm inner diameter, 25 cm length). Typically, a mixture of 0.1 g of catalyst (50–70 mesh) and 0.2 g of inert quartz (of comparable particle size) was prepared to promote uniform heat distribution and minimize localized hot-spot phenomena. The prepared catalytic bed, approximately 1 cm long, was placed at the centre of the horizontally oriented quartz tube housed inside the furnace. The total gas flow rate (50 cm3·min−1) was fed into the reactor using mass flow controllers (Brooks Instrument Smart Mass Flow), maintaining a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30,000 NmL·g−1·h−1. The feed comprised 10.0 % CO2, 40.0 % H2, and N2 as balance gas, which corresponded to a stoichiometric reactant ratio of H2/CO2 = 4. Activity tests were performed by raising the temperature from 250 to 500 °C in increments of 50 °C, then returning to 300 °C to confirm the catalyst stability throughout the measurements. The durability of the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst was also evaluated at 250–300 °C for 100 h of time-on-stream. Additionally, kinetic tests for the determination of activation energy were carried out at a GHSV of 120,000 NmL·g−1·h−1, varying the temperature from 200 to 450 °C with 25 °C increments. The reaction temperature was regulated using a chromel/alumel thermocouple located at the center of the catalytic bed. Moreover, two thermocouples were positioned at the inlet and at the outlet of the catalytic bed to measure the gradient temperature generated by reactions (maximum temperature gradient was 5 °C). Reagent and product mixtures were analysed online using a gas chromatograph (Agilent 6890 Plus) equipped with TCD and FID. Data were collected every 20 min after 1 h of steady-state operation at each temperature. N2 was employed as an internal standard for mass balance calibration. CO2 conversion ( χ CO 2 ) and CH4 yield ( Y CH 4 ) were defined as follows: (8) χ CO 2 ( % ) = F CO 2 , in − F CO 2 , out F CO 2 , in ∙ 100 (9) Y CH 4 ( % ) = F CH 4 , out F CO 2 , in ∙ 100 where F i,in and F i,out are the inlet and outlet flow (mol·s−1) of i species, respectively. The carbon balance consistently remained close to 100 ± 0.5 %. Experimental results were compared with thermodynamic equilibrium values calculated using the commercial steady-state simulation software HSC Chemistry 7.1®, which is based on the minimization of Gibbs free-energy. The CO2 methanation rate ( r CO 2 , mol·g−1·h−1), expressed as moles of CO2 consumed per unit mass of catalyst per hour, was calculated by using the following equation [25]: (10) r CO 2 = F CO 2 , in ∙ χ CO 2 W where W is the catalyst weight (g). The turnover frequency of CO2 conversion ( TOF CO 2 , s−1), defined as moles of CO2 converted per moles of surface Ni atom per second, was defined as follows [25]: (11) TOF CO 2 = F CO 2 , in ∙ χ CO 2 Ni s where the number of reduced surface Ni sites (Ni s ) was calculated based on CO-chemisorption and H2-TPR results. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 CO2 methanation activity and stability tests CO2 methanation between 250 and 500 °C has been performed over Ni-based catalysts. The results are presented in Fig. 1 in term of CO2 conversion and CH4 yield. All catalysts exhibited a volcano-shaped trend with increasing reaction temperature. As CO2 hydrogenation is a strongly exothermic reaction, lower temperatures are thermodynamically favourable but kinetically limiting due to the slow reaction rate [29,31]. Consequently, CO2 conversion increased with temperature, reaching a maximum at 350 °C for the 25Ni/Y2O3, 25Ni/ZrO2, and 25Ni/CeO2 catalysts, with the former exhibiting the highest activity under the investigated conditions (Fig. 1a). A further increase in temperature up to 500 °C resulted in a slight decrease in CO2 conversion, consistent with thermodynamic predictions [32,33]. Similarly, CH4 yield increased with temperature, indicating that the reaction was kinetically-controlled at relatively low temperatures. It achieved a maximum at 350 °C, followed by a decline due to the thermodynamic limitations of methanation as well as the occurrence of the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction [10,29]. The catalysts supported on mixed oxides, where ZrO2 and CeO2 act as structural and chemical promoters of Y2O3, did not show substantial differences in activity (Fig. 1c,d). In contrast, the incorporation of Y2O3, and mainly CeO2, into the ZrO2 support, resulted in a marked improvement in catalytic performance, enhancing both CO2 conversion (Fig. 1e) and CH4 yield (Fig. 1f). This result is not surprising, as the nature of the support influences key parameters such as morphology, acid-base characteristics, metal-support interactions, Ni dispersion, reducibility, and surface chemical composition, which in turn play a crucial role in determining the overall catalytic performance [4,14–16,34,35]. Among all the investigated catalysts, 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 exhibited the highest activity, approaching thermodynamic equilibrium CO2 conversion (95.5 %) and CH4 yield (95.0 %) at 300 °C (Fig. 1e,f). The stability of the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst was established using a 100 h time-on-stream test in the temperature range 250–300 °C, at a space velocity of 30,000 NmL·g−1·h−1, and a fixed H2/CO2 molar ratio of 4 ( Fig. 2). Almost no changes in activity were observed throughout the test, with stable CO2 conversion (72.5 and 95.5 % at 250 and 300 °C) and CH4 yield (70.1 and 95.0 % at 250 and 300 °C), indicating appropriate catalytic stability of the studied system. Upon further raising the GHSV to 120,000 NmL·g−1·h−1 ( Fig. 3a), we estimated the apparent activation energy (Ea) for the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst. The absence of limitations arising from mass and heat transfer was confirmed employing empirical criteria [25]. Fig. 3b depicts the Arrhenius plot in relation to the CO2 hydrogenation over the temperature range 200–450 °C. Accordingly, the apparent Ea is equal to 81.4 kJ/mol, agreeing with values reported in the literature for CO2 methanation on Ni-based catalysts [36–39]. 3.2 Catalyst characterization Fig. 4 presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (a,c) and the related pore size distribution (b,d) for the synthesized catalysts, while Table 1 summarizes their main textural properties. As shown in Fig. 4a, the isotherms display a typical IV type isotherm (according to BDDT classification), as is characteristic of mesoporous materials [25,40]. The distinct H1-type hysteresis loop observed for the 25Ni/ZrO2 sample was attributed to capillary condensation occurring within cylindrical mesopores, suggesting a uniform pore size distribution, as illustrated in Fig. 4b. This textural behaviour corresponds to a specific surface area of 47.8 m2/g and an average pore diameter (APD) of 8.4 nm, as reported in Table 1. In contrast, 25Ni/CeO2 and 25Ni/Y2O3 catalysts exhibited H3-type hysteresis loops, characteristic of slit-shaped pores, indicating a broad pore size distribution (Fig. 4a,b) [41,42]. These materials contain both accessible mesopores and macropores in their structure [43,44]. As a result, lower surface area and higher APD values were calculated for Ni/CeO2 (20.1 m2/g, 13.9 nm) and Ni/Y2O3 (20.7 m2/g, 34.8) systems. The introduction of ceria and yttria as structural promoters did not result in significant modifications to the pore structure (Fig. 4c,d). The XRD patterns of the as-prepared Ni-based catalysts are presented in Fig. 5. Reflections, corresponding to the oxide phases of ZrO2 (JCPDS 07–0337), CeO2 (JCPDS 04–0593), and Y2O3 (JCPDS 25–1200), were identified in both the monometallic oxide- (Fig. 5a) and mixed oxide-supported catalysts (Fig. 5b). NiO crystallite reflections (JCPDS 4–835) were also evident. The average crystallite size of NiO was estimated using the Scherrer equation, based on the most intense NiO (111) diffraction peak. The calculated values range between 6.4 and 15.8 nm, indicating variation in NiO dispersion depending on the nature of the support. The combustion-synthesized samples reducibility was studied by H2-TPR. The reduction profiles are shown in Fig. 6, while the relative reducibility values are summarized in Table 2. The TPR profile of the 25Ni/CeO2 catalyst (Fig. 6a) shows two main reduction peaks at ca. 286 and 345 °C, attributed to the reduction of Ni of different sizes. Specifically, the low-temperature peak is associated with well-dispersed NiO phase (the so-called boundary Ni-O-Ce sites), whereas the high-temperature peak can be attributed to reduction of the phase-separated surface NiO clusters over the CeO2 support [45]. The calculated hydrogen consumption was slightly lower than the H2 theoretical quantity, corresponding to 93.6 % reduction (Table 2). The Ni/ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 6a) exhibited a broad reduction peak centered at approximately 350 °C, attributed to the reduction of NiO species weakly interacting with the ZrO2 support. This was followed by a more intense peak at around 530 °C, ascribed to the reduction of bulk-like NiO particles moderately interacting with the support. The overall H2 consumption corresponds to a total NiO reducibility of 100 %, indicating that all NiO species present in the catalyst were fully reduced under the applied conditions. The TPR profiles of Ni/Y2O3 catalyst (Fig. 6a) reveals three distinct reduction peaks. The low-intensity signal at ca. 260 °C is associated to the reduction of adsorbed oxygen species interacting with NiO-induced oxygen vacancies of Y2O3. The medium temperature (at ca. 440 °C) and high temperature (at ca. 500 °C) peaks can be assigned to the reduction of bulk NiO species with different interaction extents with the support [29,46]. The overall reducibility in this case was calculated to be 88.6 %. The introduction of ceria and yttria as structural promoters did not result in significant modifications to the reduction profile (Fig. 6b). Kumar et al. [47,48] reported the reduction temperature of pure NiO to be 427 °C. Based on these observations, the authors proposed that reduction peaks below 500 °C correspond to weak interactions between nickel and the support, those in the 500–600 °C range suggest a moderate interaction, while peaks above 600 °C are indicative of a strong metal-support interaction [47–49]. In general, the position of the reduction indicates that the majority of NiO species in all the studied systems exhibit a medium-strength interaction with the support matrix [48,49]. Notably, it has been reported that NiO species with medium-strength interactions with the support can effectively enhance the performance of CO₂ methanation at low temperature [50]. Fig. 7 displays the CO2-TPD profiles of the freshly reduced catalyst, while the quantitative CO2 uptakes are reported in Table 2. Based on the CO2 desorption temperatures, three types of adsorption sites were identified: weak (< 150 °C), moderate (150 −450 °C), and strong (> 450 °C), each corresponding to different interaction strengths with the surface [25,51]. Desorption peaks at temperature lower than 150 °C are attributed to weak basic sites, generally related to surface hydroxyl groups interacting weakly with CO2, leading to the formation of bicarbonate species. Peaks in the 150–450 °C range correspond to moderate basic sites, commonly associated with metal-oxygen bonds acting as Lewis basic sites, whose basicity is enhanced by the presence of oxygen vacancies [52,53]. The limited desorption observed above 500 °C indicates a low concentration of strong basic sites, which are typically ascribed to low-coordination oxygen anions functioning as strong Lewis bases [51,54]. In contrast, a significant amount of desorbed CO2 was observed in the wide temperature range (20–450 °C). Especially, 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the high CO2 adsorption capacity (214.5 µmolCO2/g). By facilitating the adsorption and activation of CO2, the weak and medium basic sites have been reported to be crucial to CO2 methanation [55–57]. Thus, it can be speculated that the reported increase of weak and medium basic sites favoured catalytic performance in the studied reaction. TEM images of reduced 25Ni/CeO2, 25Ni/Y2O3, and 25Ni/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 8. The metal dispersion of the reduced catalysts was estimated according to the methodology described by Takeguchi et al. [58], and the results were summarized in Table 1. It can be observed that more agglomerate particles were detected on Ni/ZrO2 and Ni/CeO2 catalysts, resulting in larger Ni particle size of 31.9 and 38.9 nm, respectively (Table 1). In contrast, the Ni/Y2O3 catalyst exhibited a uniform spherical morphology (Fig. 8e-h), with significantly higher metal dispersion (5.0 %, Table 1) and smaller Ni particle size (20.4 nm, Table 1). Lattice fringes with d-spacing 2.0 Å were attributed to the (111) planes of metallic Ni. The incorporation of Y2O3 and CeO2 into the ZrO2-based formulation positively affected the catalysts morphology. Specifically, Ni particle size decreased to 14.9 and 14.4 nm (Table 1) with the addition of Y2O3 and CeO2 as structural promoters, respectively. This unexpected similarity in particle size, despite the different surface area values, suggests that metal-support interactions could play a key role in determining Ni dispersion. Furthermore, the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst exhibits well-dispersed mesoporous particles ( Fig. 9). Lattice spacings of 2.0, 3.1, and 2.9 Å, corresponding to Ni (111), CeO2 (111), and ZrO2 (111) planes, were observed (Fig. 9d), in agreement with XRD results (Fig. 5). Moreover, TEM analysis of the spent catalyst after the 100 h stability test (Fig. 9e,f) revealed no significant changes in the overall catalyst morphology. This finding, combined with the very stable catalytic performance observed during time-on-stream testing, highlights the structural robustness of the 25Ni/20CeO2–55ZrO2 catalyst under reaction conditions. To obtain information on the valence state of each element, XPS core-level spectra for the selected catalyst are presented in Fig. 10. The corresponding binding energy values and the assigned oxidation states of the elements are summarized in Table 3. The Ce 3d photoemission spectra (Fig. 10a) display two main groups of spin-orbit split peaks, which are assigned to the Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 levels. Each group contains multiple well-defined peaks, which is a distinctive feature of the mixed-valence nature of cerium, indicating the coexistence of Ce4+ and Ce3+ oxidation states [59]. Generally, the peaks marked as v, v′′, v′′′, u, u′′ and u′′′ arise from the contribution of Ce4+ species, while the peaks labelled as v°, v′′′, u°, and u′′′ originate from the contribution of Ce3+ species [60,61]. The presence of Ce3+ indicates a reduction process where Ce4+ ions have been reduced to Ce3+, often associated with creating oxygen vacancies to maintain charge neutrality. The following equation was used to calculate the relative content of Ce3+: (12) Ce 3 + = u 0 + u ′ + v 0 + v ′ ∑ u + v The relative Ce3+ content for fresh (after reduction) catalyst was 41.7 %. Interestingly, the spent catalyst shows an increased Ce3+ fraction of 52.5 %. Although the values were obtained from ex-situ analyses, they suggest that the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 sample promoted the creation of more oxygen vacancies during the methanation reaction [62]. A non-linear least-square fitting procedure using Gaussian and Lorentzian type curves showed O 1 s spectra with three distinct peaks (Fig. 10b), among which the α peak centered at 529.9 eV belongs to the characteristic peak of surface lattice oxygen of CeO2 and ZrO2 (Oα), while the β peak centered at 531.7 eV is caused by oxygen species generated by chemical adsorption (O bonded to Ce3+) in vacant sites of the lattice (Oβ) [63]. The formation of the remaining γ peak centered at around 533.4 eV can be attributed to weakly bound hydroxyl species, carbonates and water on the catalyst surface (Oγ) [64–66]. The amount of oxygen species adsorbed on the catalyst surface is positively correlated with the concentration of oxygen vacancies. Therefore, the surface oxygen vacancy concentration can be qualitatively assessed by evaluating the relative intensity of the β peak [64]. Based on the area integrals of the oxygen species, the ratio of Oβ to OT (OT = Oα + Oβ+ Oγ) was estimated. As shown in Table 3, a slight increase of Oβ from 30.1 % to 38.1 % could be observed, according to the fitting results of the Ce 3d region. Ni 2p spectra can be deconvoluted in three contributions (Fig. 10c), but there is not a general consensus about the assignment of these bands. According to literature, the peak at 853.3 eV can be assigned metallic Ni, while those at 855.7 eV and 861.4 eV are attributed to Ni2+ and its satellite peak respectively [67]. The co-existence of these two nickel species is very positive for the CO2 methanation reaction, because nickel oxide in close contact with the support are active site for CO2 chemisorption and dissociation, and Ni0 species are affective sites for H2 dissociation [67,68]. However, partial reoxidation upon exposure to air cannot be excluded. Despite this, the distribution of Ni species, combining Ni0 and Ni2+, remains after the catalytic tests, which is consistent with the catalyst stability previously demonstrated over 100 h of time-on-stream. The XPS spectrum of the Zr 3d region shown in Fig. 10d exhibits two peaks attributed to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 components, observed at binding energies of 181.7 eV and 183.9 eV, respectively. These peaks are the characteristic of Zr4+ state of zirconia, in agreement previously reported work [59,69]. Overall, the XPS results agree well with the CO2-TPD analysis, confirming that the increased Ce3+ content and higher proportion of Oβ species, both indicative of greater oxygen vacancy concentration, contribute to the enhanced basicity. This enhanced basicity, in turn, facilitates the adsorption and activation of CO2, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst [70]. Fig. 11 shows the in-situ DRIFT spectra of CO2 methanation over reduced 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst with a H2/CO2 ratio of 4. The intensity of the bands at 3020 and 1305 cm-1 (C-H stretching vibrations of *CH4) increases with the conversion rate observed during the catalytic tests performed in the fixed bed reactor (Fig. 1e,f) [69]. Moreover, mainly two types of hydroxyl group, type I and type II-A, were observed between 3500 cm and 3750 cm−1 [2]. Important information in relation to the methanation mechanism can be determined from bands below 1700 cm−1, and their behaviour with temperature [21,66]. The methanation reaction does not occur at 150 °C (Fig. 11c), and the positive bands in the spectra evidence accumulation of surface species at this temperature. The spectrum at 150 °C shows bands at 1580 (υas(CO3)), 1380 (υs(CO3)) and 1455 cm−1 (υs(CO3)), which are consistent with the presence of chelated bidentate carbonates, monodentate carbonates and bicarbonates, respectively [66]. When the temperature increased to 350 °C, bands related to bicarbonates were detected at 3620 (υ(OH)), 1455 (υs(CO3)), and 1270 cm−1 (δ(OH)). In addition, the appearance of bands at 1509 (υas(CO2)) and 1340 cm−1 (υs(CO2)) are indicative of the presence of formate species. The latter increased in intensity until reaching their maximum values at 350 °C (Fig. 11b). This observation confirms that carbonate species can be converted into bicarbonate and formate species. Moreover, formates may also result from the hydrogenation of bicarbonate intermediates. Simultaneously, two new IR signals located at 3020 and 1305 cm−1 appeared, and their intensities progressively increased. These were attributed to the υ(CH) and δ(CH) vibrational modes of gas-phase methane, respectively [71]. Additionally, an intense band at 1630 cm−1 were detected, assigned to δ(OH) vibration mode of water. The presence of CH4 and H2O demonstrates that the catalyst is active in catalysing the hydrogenation of CO2 to methane at similar temperatures, as evidenced by the signal from the mass spectrometer (Fig. 11c). Based upon the results of the in-situ DRIFT experiment discussed above, a potential mechanism for CO2hydrogenation to methane over 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 is proposed ( Fig. 12). At 150 °C, CO2 adsorbed onto the catalyst support predominantly as carbonate species, with a minor contribution of bicarbonates. According to CO2-TPD results, bicarbonate species preferentially adsorb on weak basic sites, commonly associated with surface hydroxyl groups, whereas carbonates typically form on moderate basic sites through interaction of CO₂ with Lewis basic sites, such as metal-oxygen bonds, whose basicity is enhanced by the presence of oxygen vacancies [53,70]. Therefore, CO2 initially interacted with *OH groups and oxygen vacancies on the CeO2-ZrO2 support, facilitating the formation of *HCO3 and mainly *CO3 species, in agreement with the XPS results. Above 200 °C, these intermediates underwent progressive hydrogenation to formate species and methane. Oxygen vacancies not only enhance CO2 activation but also weaken Ni-O interactions, thereby promoting the formation of metallic Ni0 sites [70]. Hydrogen then dissociates on these metallic Ni0 sites and subsequently migrates (spillover) to adjacent adsorbed species on the support [72–74]. Therefore, the “formate route” is proposed as the dominant route for methane formation, proceeding via the sequence CO2 → (bi)carbonates → formates → CH4, as previously reported by other authors [2,72,73,75]. The absence of bands related to Ni-carbonyl species further supports this interpretation. In addition, the increase in the intensity of the formates IR bands with rising temperature, suggests that they are key intermediate species in CO2 methanation. Indeed, formate hydrogenation appears to be the rate-determining step of the overall reaction [72]. 3.3 Correlations between catalytic performance and catalyst physico-chemical properties Table 4 summarizes the reaction rates as well as the TOF values of the prepared catalysts, along with their CO2 conversions and CH4 yields at 250 °C. The data clearly show that the nature of the metal oxide support significantly influences the catalytic performance. The following order was established: rateCO2 (molCO2·g−1·h−1): 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 > 25Ni/20Y2O3-55ZrO2 > 25Ni/20CeO2-55Y2O3 > 25Ni/Y2O3 > 25Ni/20ZrO2-55Y2O3 > 25Ni/ZrO2 > 25Ni/CeO2 TOF (s−1): 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 > 25Ni/20CeO2-55Y2O3 > 25Ni/ZrO2 > 25Ni/Y2O3 > 25Ni/20Y2O3-55ZrO2 > 25Ni/20ZrO2-55Y2O3 > 25Ni/CeO2 The CO2 methanation rate correlated well with the activity parameter (χCO2 and YCH4), whereas a slightly different trend was observed for the TOF values (Table 4). Nevertheless, the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst consistently exhibited the best performance in terms of both reaction rate and TOF. The correlation between catalyst performance and physicochemical properties was further explored to identify the key characteristic governing the methanation performance. In particular, CO2-TPD analysis revealed a high CO2 adsorption capacity for 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 (Fig. 7, Table 2), in line with XPS data (Fig. 10, Table 3), which indicated an increased concentration of Ce3+ and surface-adsorbed oxygen species (Oβ, Oγ). These features, often associated with surface hydroxyls and oxygen vacancies, are believed to serve as active basic sites for CO2 adsorption and activation. The increased proportions of Oβ (from 30.1 % to 38.1 %), Oγ (from 27.0 % to 34.6 %) and Ce3+ (from 41.7 % to 52.5 %) after the catalytic test further support the formation of additional CO2 adsorption sites during the reaction. Accordingly, both CO2-TPD and XPS consistently indicate that the enhanced basicity and defect-rich surface of the studied catalyst contribute to its superior performance [76]. A good correlation between the CO2 reaction rate and the weak-to-moderate basicity can be observed, as shown in Fig. 13, which reveals a linear relationship between rCO2 and the number of basic sites. Indeed, a higher concentration of weak-to-moderate basic sites promotes CO2 adsorption and activation in the form of carbonate and bicarbonate species, which are readily converted into formate intermediates and subsequently hydrogenated to CH4, as literature reported [54,69,77–79]. As for the rates, the TOF values exhibited a linear increase with the number of weak-to-moderate basic sites (Fig. 13), suggesting that the reaction proceeds via two different types of active sites. Furthermore, CO-chemisorption measurements revealed an improved Ni dispersion on the catalyst surface, which is known to facilitate efficient H2 dissociation. The high dispersion of Ni particles increases the availability of accessible metallic sites, enhancing the hydrogenation step and contributing significantly to the overall catalytic performance [80]. In their review, Molinet-Chinaglia et al. [81] highlighted the low-temperature activity of Ni-based catalysts across various studies, emphasizing the role of basic sites in promoting CO2 activation and conversion, as well as the relevance of dual-site mechanisms involving both metallic and basic components. Liu et al. [82] identified carbonates and bicarbonates formed on basic MgO sites, along with hydrogen species adsorbed on Ni surfaces, as key intermediates in the methanation reaction. Notably, they reported a linear correlation between TOF and the density of basic sites on Ni/MgAlOx catalysts, supporting a cooperative catalytic mechanism involving both Ni and MgO. In line with these findings, the results obtained for the catalyst studied in the present work suggested a two-site model mechanism. A synergistic interaction between Ni and basic sites is likely at play. While Ni sites are primarily responsible for H2 dissociation, the basic sites promote CO2 activation and the formation of surface intermediates, ultimately enhancing the overall efficiency of the methanation process. 4 Conclusions In this study, a series of 25 wt% Ni-based catalysts were successfully synthesized using solution combustion synthesis (SCS) to investigate their performance in CO2 methanation. Among the investigated systems, the 25Ni/20CeO2-55ZrO2 catalyst demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance, achieving CO2 conversion rates of 72.5 % and 95.5 % at 250 °C and 300 °C, respectively, with remarkable stability maintained over 100 h of continuous operation. The superior performance of this catalyst is attributed to a synergistic combination of structural and surface properties. CO₂-TPD and XPS analyses revealed a high density of weak-to-moderate basic sites, linked to the presence of surface hydroxyl groups and oxygen vacancies. These features enhance CO2 adsorption and activation. Furthermore, CO-chemisorption measurements and TEM analysis confirmed a high dispersion of Ni nanoparticles on the CeO2-ZrO2 support, which increases the number of exposed Ni0 sites essential for efficient H2 dissociation and spillover. In-situ DRIFT-MS studies provided mechanistic insights, identifying a reaction pathway in which CO2 is adsorbed as carbonate and bicarbonate species, subsequently hydrogenated to formates and finally converted into methane. The increasing intensity of formate-related IR bands with temperature suggests that formates are key intermediates, and their hydrogenation represents the rate-determining step of the overall reaction. The observed linear relationship between TOF and the number of weak-to-moderate basic sites suggests a dual-site reaction mechanism: basic sites facilitate CO2 activation and the formation of surface intermediates, while highly dispersed Ni sites enable efficient H2 dissociation and subsequent hydrogenation steps. Overall, this work highlights the critical role of support in enhancing low-temperature CO2 methanation. The findings underline the potential of the Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst as a highly efficient and stable system for power-to-gas (P2G) technologies and sustainable CO2 utilization. coredata.dc:description: The methanation of carbon dioxide via the Sabatier process is attracting growing attention for power-to-gas (P2G) application. In the current study, a series of 25 wt% Ni-based catalysts were synthesized using solution combustion synthesis (SCS) to investigate the influence of the support on the methanation performance. The results showed that Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited superior activity, achieving 72.5 % and 95.5 % CO2 conversion at 250 °C and 300 °C, respectively, while maintaining excellent stability over 100 h of time-on-stream. CO2-TPD analysis revealed that weak-to-moderate basic sites played a key role in enhancing catalytic activity. This is consistent with XPS results, which indicated a high concentration of surface hydroxyl groups and oxygen vacancies, responsible for the enhanced basicity of the CeO2-ZrO2 support. Additionally, the CO-chemisorption measurements confirmed improved Ni dispersion, further contributing to efficient H2 activation. In situ DRIFT-MS studies identified a reaction pathway involving CO2 adsorption as carbonate and bicarbonate species, followed by stepwise hydrogenation to methane via formate intermediates. The correlation between turnover frequency (TOF) and the number of weak-to-moderate basic sites supports a dual-site reaction mechanism, where basic sites facilitate CO2 activation and Ni sites promote H2 dissociation, both contributing to the remarkable low-temperature carbon dioxide methanation activity.
